instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should allow users to enter video search keywords through a shared search bar.Re2 The system should provide checkboxes to allow users to choose whether to include Torrent resources in the search.Re3 The system should provide checkboxes to allow users to choose whether to include video streaming resources in the search.Re4 The system should provide checkboxes to allow users to choose whether to search only video hosting sites (such as YouTube).Re5 The system should provide checkboxes to allow users to choose whether to search video link sites (such as SurfTheChannel).Re6 The system should be able to query compatible torrent site databases and return relevant information about torrent files, including: number of seeds, number of peers, file size, release date, and webpage link.Re7 The system should be able to query compatible video streaming site databases and obtain complete video names, durations, release dates, and video links from video hosting sites.Re8 The system should be able to query compatible video streaming site databases and obtain program names, episode names, and webpage links from video link sites.Re9 The system should display torrent search results and video streaming search results separately in tabbed sections on the search results page.Re10 Within the video streaming results tab, the display area should be divided into two parts: the upper part showing results from video hosting sites, and the lower part showing results from video link sites.Re11 The system should allow users to sort search results by name, size, duration, date, etc., in ascending or descending order by clicking on column headers.Re12 The system should provide pagination functionality, displaying 100 results per page by default, and allowing users to browse subsequent results through a 'Next Page' button.Re13 The system should display a message 'No results were found for this search.' when no search results are found.Re14 The system should allow users to filter search results, choosing to display content from specific sites or exclude certain sites.Re15 The system should provide a favorites feature, allowing users to save their favorite video links for future access.Re16 The system should provide parental control features, allowing users to filter out videos containing adult content or other inappropriate content for certain age groups.Re17 The system should support online database updates, enabling the development team to remotely add or modify the list of searchable torrent and video sites.Re18 The system should not display torrent results with zero seeds to ensure download feasibility.Re19 The system should not display torrent results with a rating below 1 to ensure resource reliability.Re20 The system should open the selected video or torrent page in the user's default browser via hyperlink.Re21 The system's response time for querying any site should not exceed 5 seconds.Re22 The time it takes to send hyperlinks to the default browser should be less than 1 second.Re23 The system's startup loading time should be less than 10 seconds.Re24 The system's sorting operation response time should be less than 0.1 seconds.Re25 The system should be designed to run cross-platform, supporting Microsoft Windows XP/Vista, Mac OS X, and major Linux distributions.Re26 The system should be compatible with mainstream web browsers such as Internet Explorer, Firefox, and Safari.Re27 The system should regularly (monthly) review websites in the database to ensure that illegal or harmful content is not exposed to users.Re28 The system should not store user data or host any video content, providing only external link indexing services.Re29 The system should undergo comprehensive legal review before release to ensure compliance with relevant laws and regulations and avoid liability for infringement.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should provide a migration workflow that supports batch conversion from ARC files to WARC files and has configuration management policies.Re2 The system should provide a web user interface for creating and managing migration configurations, with configuration information persistently saved as files or stored in a database.Re3 The system should provide a command-line migration tool (arc_warc_migrate) that supports converting a collection of ARC files to WARC files based on a configuration file.Re4 Users should be able to specify metadata related to the conversion (such as institution, context, crawler, collection name, etc.) and write it into the generated WARC file.Re5 The system should support automatically generating migration metadata and writing it into the WARC file, including operating system type, original ARC file name, size, digest, conversion timestamp, record offset, etc.Re6 The system should support calling external tools or services (such as database queries, shell commands, Web services) to generate and save migration metadata.Re7 During migration, persistent, opaque, unique, and globally unique identifiers (such as NOID, ARK, UUID) should be used to identify WARC records.Re8 The system should call external tools (such as ClamAV) to scan files for viruses and malware before conversion.Re9 The system should support integrating external file format recognition tools (such as DROID, JHOVE, FILE) and write the recognition results into the WARC-identified-payload-type field of WARC records.Re10 The ARC to WARC migration process should support distributed deployment, allowing parallel execution on multiple machines and ease of deployment.Re11 The system should support dynamically enabling or disabling logging during the migration process.Re12 The system should support setting software checkpoints (such as start-trans, end-trans) during processing to ensure the integrity of atomic operations.Re13 The system should support 'dry-run migration' to simulate the migration process, generate performance reports, detect corrupted ARC files, and estimate time without actually generating WARC files.Re14 The system should use checksum mechanisms to detect and report duplicate WARC records, supporting the use of a central database to store processed records for deduplication comparison.Re15 The verification tool (arc_warc_verify) should be able to match and verify WARC records with original ARC records using metadata included in the WARC file.Re16 The verification process should be based on payload checksum comparison to confirm the integrity of the migrated content.Re17 The system should support sampling verification for large-scale collections, randomly selecting samples according to the distribution ratio of record types for quick verification.Re18 The verification tool should support using Heritrix's arcreader component to doubly verify whether the original ARC records have been correctly converted to WARC format.Re19 The system should support 'round trip validation': re-converting the generated WARC files back to ARC format and comparing checksums to verify consistency.Re20 The system should provide a WARC repackaging tool (warc_repackage) that supports filtering and generating new WARC file sets based on conditions such as URL (regular expression), MIME type, file size, timestamp, etc.Re21 The repackaging tool should support filtering records based on any field in the WARC specification.Re22 The repackaging process should support pre-processing and post-processing operations (such as script calls) and allow blocking specific files or records through return values.Re23 Each WARC file generated by repackaging should contain user-defined metadata records describing the extraction context (such as filter conditions, source files, etc.).Re24 The system should provide a WARC summary tool (warc_summary) that supports generating various reports, including: content summary, MIME type statistics, hostname statistics, status code frequency, pseudo-crawl logs, etc.Re25 The summary tool should support using the filters of the repackaging tool to generate statistical reports for specific subsets.Re26 The system should support exporting summary reports in multiple formats, such as XML, CSV.Re27 The system should enhance the WARC browser by integrating the results of the summary tool and displaying aggregated WARC summary information in the web interface in chart form.Re28 The enhanced WARC browser should display the list of WARC files and their storage locations.Re29 The system should provide a WARC comparison tool (warc_compare) that supports differential analysis of WARC sets from multiple crawl tasks based on conditions such as timestamp, hostname, etc.Re30 The comparison tool should provide a 'diff' function to identify content changes between different WARC sets (such as added, deleted, modified pages).Re31 The system should support generating difference charts to visually demonstrate change trends between multiple WARC sets, aiding quality assurance.Re32 The system should support viewing 'deltas' between crawl tasks to assess the quality of repeated crawls.Re33 The enhanced WARC browser should implement server-side rewriting functions to improve the browsing experience of archived content.Re34 The system should integrate proxy mode into the WARC browser, supporting access to archived content via a proxy.Re35 The system should integrate full-text search functionality (Search Tools project) to provide indexing and search capabilities for the WARC browser and command line.Re36 The tools should support handling multiple WARC files simultaneously, allowing selection or grouping through explicit naming, wildcard matching, size limits, item quantity, etc.Re37 The system should support distributed processing and data transfer to expand the capability of handling large-scale collections.Re38 The tools should provide optimal performance, efficiently handling large-scale collections and optimizing I/O performance.Re39 The system should support running on multiple machines but does not handle hardware failures (this is out of scope).Re40 The implementation should avoid unnecessary technical dependencies and not include integration technologies developed for specific partners.Re41 The system should conform to Java development environment standards, providing web services, RESTful APIs, and other interfaces.Re42 The system should provide logging functionality to track command execution progress, processing duration, output level, etc.Re43 The system should provide easily modifiable Shell script encapsulation to enhance the usability of primary commands.Re44 The system should support running in restricted mode, operating only on selected subsets of collections (such as by name, random sampling).```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should display hyperlinks and descriptions for users to perform specific functions (in accordance with UIS specifications) Re2 Users should be able to view the function hyperlinks and explanatory text in the management module Re3 Users should be able to click on hyperlinks to select and enter the corresponding functional operation page Re4 Users with administrator privileges should be able to create new users manually or based on templates Re5 When creating new users, the system should associate them with specified roles, departments, design codes, and laboratory locations Re6 During the user creation process, the system should verify whether the username and display name already exist in the system, and if they do, it should display an error message Re7 When adding a user, the system should verify their status in Active Directory, and if they are inactive, it should display an error message Re8 When users create accounts from templates, they should inherit all role settings defined in the template Re9 Administrators should be able to manually add additional roles when creating users using templates Re10 The system should save complete information of newly created users and their permission configurations to the database Re11 The system should verify before submission that at least one role, department, design code, and laboratory location have been associated Re12 The system should verify that users have filled out required fields (username and display name), otherwise it should prevent saving and display an error message Re13 The system should display a standard error or warning message when users attempt to save incomplete user information Re14 The system should clear entered data when users click the 'Cancel' button Re15 The system should return to the xxx page when users click the 'Close' button without entering any data Re16 Required fields in each user interface should be marked with a red asterisk (*) to remind users to fill them out Re17 The system should provide a 'Help' hyperlink in the upper right corner of each user interface for accessing online help Re18 After clicking the 'Help' link, the system should pop up a help window, defaulting to the '[system name] Overview' page Re19 The help system should contain topic information consistent with the content of the user manual and support hyperlink navigation Re20 The left side of the help window should provide a navigation frame, allowing users to browse different help topics by clicking links Re21 The help system should support full-text search functionality to facilitate quick information lookup by users Re22 The help system should provide an index, supporting deep content retrieval by users Re23 The help system should include a glossary explaining professional terms related to the company and system Re24 All help pages should display the company logo and maintain a unified color scheme and background style Re25 The project team should present UI prototypes to stakeholders early in development Re26 If project progress allows, the project team should permit stakeholders to make reasonable adjustments to the user interfaces of new features Re27 System updates in the production environment should be scheduled between 7 PM Tuesday and 7 AM the following day Re28 Before new features go live, the development team must conduct appropriate testing (such as unit testing, integration testing) Re29 Before deployment to the production environment, sufficient time must be reserved for users to conduct acceptance testing (UAT) Re30 The development team must follow a unified coding standard and gradually adapt existing standards when modifying code Re31 The system should log errors, warnings, and informational messages to external log files on the application server Re32 When users are directed to a system error page, the system should record an error log and send a notification email to the customer service email address Re33 The system should continue to use a single SQL Server 2008 database as data storage Re34 All feature development should be based on the .NET 3.5 platform and xx language Re35 The development team should prioritize mature open-source frameworks and avoid proprietary custom components Re36 Before each deployment to the production environment, a technical lead (Technical Owner/Lead) must sign off on the release approval Re37 The development team should integrate the system weekly and deploy updates to the pre-production (Staging) environment Re38 Each regularly built version must be labeled (Label) in the source code control system Re39 All build processes must be based on the code versions marked in the source control system Re40 After each deployment to the Staging environment, the development team should send version release notes to project members via email Re41 All code changes must undergo code review by a technical manager before being committed to the source code repository Re42 The QA team must perform regression testing on each regularly built version Re43 The system must retain its existing HIPAA compliance capabilities Re44 All new features must be designed and implemented in compliance with HIPAA requirements```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should support generating RET messages to confirm the receipt status of received ERS messages (such as DAT, DEL, COR)Re2 The system should support recording the message number of the referenced ERS message through the ON attribute (for non-UK vessels), in the format 'AAAYYYYMMDD999999'Re3 The system should support recording the GB record number of the referenced ERS message through the GBR ON attribute (for UK vessels), in the format 'RSSNoYYYYMMDD999999'Re4 The system should support including the return status (RS) attribute in RET messages to indicate the success or failure status of message reception, with status codes referring to the EC ERS official websiteRe5 The system should support providing an optional rejection reason (RE) attribute in RET messages, allowing the cause of operation failure to be explained in free text formRe6 The system must be able to associate each confirmation message (RET) with the corresponding outbound report and operation type (DAT, DEL, COR)Re7 The system must provide a mechanism to indicate that the report has been successfully confirmed, and can display error information or additional data from the confirmation messageRe8 The system must alert the captain if no confirmation message is received within a preset time limitRe9 The system should support the COE sub-declaration for declaring catches on board (according to the species SPE sub-declaration list)Re10 The system should support generating COX messages to declare departure from specific fisheries management areas (such as resource recovery zones or western waters)Re11 The system should include the exit date (DA) in COX messages, in the format 'YYYY-MM-DD', compliant with UTC standardsRe12 The system should include the exit time (TI) in COX messages, in the format 'HH:MM', compliant with UTC standardsRe13 The system should include the target species code (TS) in COX messages, represented by a single-letter alphabetic code, following the EC ERS official standard (not applicable for other fishing activities)Re14 The system should include the UK-specific fishing effort area code (GBRFE) in COX messages, with the code list referencing the UK Fisheries official websiteRe15 The system should include the position sub-declaration (POS) in COX messages, used to report the geographical location at the time of exitRe16 The system should include the cross-zone fishing identifier (GBRTRZ) in COX messages, with values 'Y' or 'N', indicating whether cross-zone fishing has occurredRe17 The system should include the reference serial number (GBRS RN) of the ELSS software in OPS messages, used to identify the software instance sending LOG messagesRe18 The system should support generating DEL messages to request the deletion of previously sent ERS dataRe19 The system should support specifying the record number (RN) of the record to be deleted in DEL messages, in the format 'AAAYYYYMMDD999999' (for non-UK vessels)Re20 The system should support specifying the GB record number (GBRR N) of the record to be deleted in DEL messages, in the format 'RSSNoYYYYMMDD999999' (for UK vessels)Re21 The system should support setting the test flag (TS) in OPS messages, with a value of '1' indicating that the message is a test messageRe22 The system should support pushing logbook or sales document information to the ERS system via the DAT operationRe23 The system should support returning confirmation responses to previous DAT, DEL, and COR operations via the RET operationRe24 The system should support requesting the deletion of sent data via the DEL operationRe25 The system should support requesting corrections to sent data via the COR operationRe26 The system should support generating DAT messages to push log data, with the message start marker being DATRe27 The system should support including ERS elements in DAT messages as the content of the pushed data```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should provide a boot menu upon startup, allowing users to select default mode, load into memory, safe graphics settings, failsafe mode, or run a memory test.Re2 The system should allow users to select the keyboard layout (Keymap) at startup.Re3 The system should provide a multilingual selection menu, supporting users in choosing the display language of the interface.Re4 The system should provide a desktop environment with access points for functions such as exit, screenshot, terminal, GParted main window, information, and screen resolution adjustment.Re5 The system should provide a main window interface displaying the graphical partition layout and detailed partition list of the selected device.Re6 The system should allow users to refresh the list of connected devices to recognize newly inserted storage devices (such as USB flash drives).Re7 The system should support an operation queue mechanism where all partition operations default to pending status, allowing users to choose 'Apply' to execute or 'Undo' to cancel.Re8 The system should allow users to undo the last operation or clear all pending operations.Re9 The system should provide a feature to view device information, displaying detailed information about the selected disk, including model, size, heads, sectors, cylinders, etc.Re10 The system should allow users to create a new partition table for a disk (such as msdos, gpt), warning users before execution that this operation will delete all data.Re11 The system should support creating new partitions, allowing users to set partition size and position using sliders or manual input.Re12 The system should allow users to select the partition type (primary, logical, extended) when creating a partition.Re13 The system should allow users to select the file system type (such as ext4, NTFS, FAT32, etc.) or choose not to format when creating a partition.Re14 The system should allow users to set a label (Label) for a partition when creating it.Re15 The system should support deleting existing partitions, with changes taking effect after application.Re16 The system should support resizing or moving partitions, maintaining data integrity as much as possible during the process.Re17 The system should support copying partitions to the clipboard.Re18 The system should support pasting copied partitions to unallocated space or another disk, allowing adjustments to size and position.Re19 The system should allow users to format existing partitions to supported file system types.Re20 The system should support unmounting mounted partitions.Re21 The system should provide functionality to manage partition flags (Flags), such as setting boot, hidden, etc.Re22 The system should support checking and repairing file systems.Re23 The system should allow users to modify or set labels for partitions that support labels.Re24 The system should provide a screenshot function, allowing users to capture the entire desktop or a specified active window.Re25 The system should integrate terminal functionality, allowing advanced users to perform command-line operations.Re26 The system should allow users to store screenshots or saved files on external devices.Re27 The system should provide a function to display information about GParted and its software packages.Re28 The system should support adjusting screen resolution.Re29 The system should display the current date and time.Re30 The system should support multiple file systems, including ext2/ext3/ext4, FAT16/FAT32, NTFS, reiserfs, xfs, hfs/hfs+, linux-swap, etc.Re31 The system should support hardware RAID, motherboard BIOS RAID, and Linux software RAID devices.Re32 The system should act as a graphical front-end for GNU Parted (libparted), utilizing its libraries for device and partition table detection and manipulation.Re33 The system should rely on third-party file system tools (such as e2fsprogs, ntfsprogs, dosfstools, etc.) to support specific file system operations.Re34 The system should be designed as a LiveCD/LiveUSB boot environment, capable of running without installation and leaving no trace after reboot.Re35 The system should run on computers with x86 architecture, compatible with different operating system environments (by booting from media).Re36 The system should provide online documentation, help manuals, and forum links to facilitate user support.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should allow users to remotely monitor and control the temperature, humidity, lighting, security systems, and small appliances in their home through network-ready devices such as computers, mobile phones, or PDAs. Re2 The system should support user operations via a personal webpage on the DigitalHome Web server or a local home server. Re3 The system should communicate with sensors and controllers in the home through a home wireless gateway device. Re4 The system should include a digital programmable thermostat for monitoring and regulating the temperature of enclosed spaces. Re5 Users should be able to read the current temperature value at the location of the thermostat. Re6 Users should be able to set the thermostat's target temperature between 60°F and 80°F, with 1-degree increments. Re7 The system should support up to eight thermostats that can be controlled individually or collectively to achieve independent temperature control in different areas. Re8 Each thermostat should support the setting of temperature schedules with up to 24 one-hour periods per day of the week. Re9 Manually set thermostat temperatures should remain effective until the scheduled or default time period ends. Re10 The system should support both Fahrenheit (°F) and Celsius (°C) temperature units. Re11 The system should be compatible with centralized HVAC systems (such as gas, electric, solar, etc.) and comply with ASHRAE standards. Re12 The system should include a digital programmable humidity controller (humidistat) for monitoring and regulating indoor humidity. Re13 Users should be able to read the current humidity value at the location of the humidity controller. Re14 Users should be able to set the humidity level between 30% and 60%, with 1% increments. Re15 The system should support up to eight humidity controllers, each controlling an independent space. Re16 Each humidity controller should support the setting of humidity schedules with up to 24 one-hour periods per day of the week. Re17 Manually set humidity values should remain effective until the scheduled or default time period ends. Re18 The system should support communication with thermostats and humidity controllers via wireless signals. Re19 The security system should include magnetic door/window contact sensors for detecting unauthorized entry. Re20 The system should manage up to 50 door/window contact sensors. Re21 The system should be able to activate audio-visual alarm devices (one sound alarm and one light alarm subsystem). Re22 When a contact sensor is triggered (opened), the system should automatically activate the security alarm. Re23 The system should provide programmable appliance management functions, allowing users to remotely turn on/off small appliances and lighting devices. Re24 The system should support up to 100 115-volt, 10-amp power switches. Re25 The system should display the status (on or off) of each power switch, reflecting the operational status of the connected appliances. Re26 The system should be able to remotely toggle the state (on/off) of power switches to control appliances. Re27 Manually changed power switch states should remain effective until the scheduled or default time period ends. Re28 The system should provide digital home planning functions (DH Planner), allowing users to preset home parameters (temperature, humidity, security, appliance status) for specific time periods. Re29 The system should provide monthly planning functions, allowing users to create or modify environmental parameter schedules for up to four periods per day for a future month. Re30 Users should be able to override preset schedule parameters through the website or manual switches. Re31 The system should be able to generate management reports for any month within the past two years. Re32 Monthly reports should include daily average, maximum (with time), and minimum (with time) temperature and humidity values for each thermostat and humidity controller. Re33 Monthly reports should record the dates and times of all security alarm triggers. Re34 Monthly reports should indicate periods when the system was not operational. Re35 Environmental status displays (temperature, humidity, sensors, switches) should update at least every two seconds. Re36 The data acquisition rate for sensors (temperature, humidity, contact, power status) should be no less than 10 Hz. Re37 All environmental sensors or control devices should maintain communication within 1000 feet of the main control device. Re38 The system should have high reliability, with a failure rate of no more than once every 10,000 hours. Re39 The system should have backup and recovery mechanisms, automatically backing up system data (configuration, parameters, schedules, usage data) daily. Re40 In the event of a failure (power outage, network interruption, etc.), the system should be able to restore data from the most recent backup. Re41 All system operations should have exception handling mechanisms, returning clear error messages to the user. Re42 The system should implement user authentication and information encryption using technologies such as Transport Layer Security (TLS). Re43 User login to the system should provide username and password verification. Re44 The system should provide online user documentation, including frequently asked questions (FAQs). Re45 User documentation should explain how to set system parameters and read sensor values, noting setting limits and precision. Re46 User documentation should include instructions for using the DH Planner. Re47 The system should be designed with a modular structure for ease of maintenance and integration into future commercial versions. Re48 System development should follow HomeOwner coding standards and relevant IEEE standards (e.g., IEEE830, 1008, 1016, 1028). Re49 All system documentation (requirements, design, code, test plans) should conform to HomeOwner document formats and be archived. Re50 The system should use object-oriented development methods, modeled using UML 2.0, with exceptions requiring CIO approval.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should allow users to create and manage user accounts, including username, password, name, email address, and group membership information.Re2 The system should support user login and authenticate identity through internal or external authentication modules.Re3 The system should allow users to modify personal account information, including password, email address, and name.Re4 The system should support user account role management, including Contributor, Approver, and Publisher.Re5 The system should control user operations based on role permissions: Contributors can create, edit, and submit content; Approvers can approve content; Publishers can schedule or immediately publish content.Re6 The system should support the deactivation and reactivation of user accounts; accounts with associated history can only be deactivated and not deleted.Re7 The system should provide a password reset function, supporting both self-service recovery by users and password resets by administrators.Re8 The system should support linking user accounts to external social service accounts (such as Facebook, Twitter, Flickr, YouTube, etc.).Re9 The system should provide standardized interfaces for unified management of publishing and data aggregation across multiple external social platforms.Re10 The system should support the creation of marketing campaigns (Campaigns), each campaign including a name, content, publication schedule, and permission settings.Re11 The system should allow users to schedule publication plans for campaigns, automatically posting content to multiple social platforms at specified times.Re12 The system should support various content types, including text, images, audio, and video.Re13 The system should provide a visual calendar scheduling interface, supporting drag-and-drop arrangement of content publication times.Re14 The system should provide a dashboard displaying key metrics such as click-through rates, page views, and comment counts for campaigns.Re15 The system should support the extension of dedicated metrics via service plugins, such as 'retweets' for Twitter.Re16 The system should provide an 'Explore' view, supporting keyword monitoring and social sentiment tracking.Re17 The system should aggregate user feedback from various social platforms, such as @replies and comments, for users to view and respond to uniformly.Re18 The system should support setting up keyword alerts to monitor the dynamics of specific topics on social networks.Re19 The system should ensure secure communication between the client and server using TLS encryption.Re20 The system should ensure that only valid users (not disabled or deleted) can log in to the system.Re21 The system should support administrator configuration of automatic logout timeout to enhance account security.Re22 The system should support configuring alerts for multiple failed login attempts and notify the system administrator via email.Re23 The system should support email notification functions for sending system messages and security warnings.Re24 The system should support data backup, with incremental backups not causing service interruptions and full backups having downtime not exceeding 10 minutes.Re25 The system should provide a navigation interface based on tags, including four major functional modules: 'Dashboard,' 'Create,' 'Schedule,' and 'Explore.'Re26 The system should support batch scheduling of content publication to improve operational efficiency.Re27 The system should allow users to view, edit, and delete published campaign content.Re28 The system should support multi-user collaboration, allowing multiple users to participate in the same marketing campaign.Re29 The system should support approval workflows, where content must be approved before it can be published.Re30 The system should support the unpublishing of already published content.Re31 The system should support cross-platform synchronization, allowing users to access the system via any modern browser.Re32 The system should be compatible with mainstream network protocols (HTTP/1.1, SMTP, TCP/IP) to ensure communication compatibility.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should allow users to select a PDF file for splitting operations through a graphical interface.Re2 The system should support multiple ways of splitting PDF files, including: splitting by single page, splitting by specified number of pages, splitting by odd and even pages, splitting by specified page numbers, splitting by file size, and splitting by bookmark levels.Re3 The system should allow users to customize the naming pattern for output files after splitting, supporting variables such as [CURRENTPAGE], [FILENUMBER], [TIMESTAMP], [BASENAME], and [BOOKMARK_NAME].Re4 The system should allow users to set the save directory for the split files, and support saving in the same directory as the source file or a custom path.Re5 The system should support compressing the output PDF files and allow users to choose the PDF version of the generated files.Re6 The system should only allow one PDF file splitting task at a time.Re7 The system should support users entering a password to open protected PDF files.Re8 The system should allow users to merge multiple PDF files or parts of their pages into a new file.Re9 The system should allow users to specify the page range for each file during merging, supporting formats like 'all', 'page-page', 'page-', individual pages, and multiple ranges separated by commas.Re10 The system should allow users to adjust the order of files to be merged and support automatic sorting via table column sorting functions.Re11 The system should allow users to export the list of merged files as an XML file for command-line tool input.Re12 The system should support retaining form data when merging PDF documents that contain forms.Re13 The system should allow users to set the output path, compression options, and PDF version for the merged file.Re14 The system should only allow mixing two PDF files simultaneously.Re15 The system should support alternating the mixing of pages from two documents and allow users to configure the number of pages extracted from each document per step.Re16 The system should allow users to choose whether to read pages in reverse order from the first or second document for mixing.Re17 The system should allow users to batch rotate all pages of multiple PDF files.Re18 The system should support clockwise rotation settings of 90°, 180°, 270°, etc.Re19 The system should allow users to select rotating all pages, only even-numbered pages, or only odd-numbered pages.Re20 The system should allow users to rearrange the page order within a single PDF file through a visual interface.Re21 The system should provide a thumbnail preview function, supporting drag-and-drop sorting for single or multiple pages.Re22 The system should support left/right rotation, deletion, restoration, and reverse sorting operations on selected pages.Re23 The system should provide an integrated image viewer to preview the content of selected pages.Re24 The system should support zooming features, allowing users to adjust the display size of thumbnails.Re25 The system should allow users to visually select pages from multiple PDF files to combine them into a new PDF document.Re26 The system should provide a thumbnail area for source documents and an editing area for target documents in the visual combination interface.Re27 The system should allow users to drag pages from source documents into target documents and support reordering and editing.Re28 The system should allow users to save the current workspace configuration for subsequent loading and reuse.Re29 The system should support loading previously saved workspace configuration files.Re30 The system should provide a log panel to display status and error information in real-time during operation execution.Re31 The system should allow users to configure the default workspace to load at startup.Re32 The system should provide setting functions, allowing users to customize runtime parameters such as memory usage and default save paths.Re33 The system should support a command-line interface (Console), allowing all core functionalities to be executed via command line.Re34 The system should be developed based on Java, supporting operation on any platform with JVM 1.6 or higher installed.Re35 The system should be released under the GNU GPL v2 license to ensure open and free use of the source code.Re36 The system should depend on the Java runtime environment (JRE 1.6+) to operate normally.Re37 The system's user interface should be implemented based on Java Swing to ensure cross-platform consistency.Re38 The system should provide corresponding documentation support for different users, including user manuals, FAQs, and online Wiki resources.Re39 The system should ensure that the file compression feature is only available for PDF versions 1.5 and above.Re40 The system should limit the number of digits for the [FILENUMBER] variable to a maximum of 10 digits.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:```Re1 The system should support model sharing between internal and external entities of the enterprise, including business-to-business (B2B) and business-to-consumer (B2C) scenarios.Re2 The system should provide a unified data management mechanism to meet the management needs of general data, smart grid data, non-smart grid data, and their intersection scenarios.Re3 The system should support architectural design requirements related to smart grids, ensuring compatibility with existing business units, application systems, and project architectures.Re4 The system should achieve logical decomposition of application capabilities, supporting independent deployment and management of core function modules such as data validation.Re5 The system should have self-healing and self-discovery capabilities to enhance maintainability and automation levels.Re6 The system should define and support integration patterns between new and old technology systems, achieving effective interface connections with legacy systems.Re7 The system should support standard model integration based on the IEC Common Information Model (CIM), achieving semantic consistency.Re8 The system should use the IEC CIM standard to support message communication mechanisms based on standards.Re9 The system should build persistent data storage based on the IEC CIM, ensuring standardized data structures.Re10 The system should use the IEC CIM to construct semantic models that support the NIST framework, promoting cross-system interoperability.Re11 The information model of the system should clearly define common terms for data concepts to ensure semantic consistency.Re12 The information model of the system should support alias mechanisms for data concepts to accommodate terminology habits of different business departments.Re13 The system should establish an enterprise-level semantic management mechanism to support the initialization and continuous maintenance of semantic models.Re14 The system should adopt a reference architecture to guide the construction of the enterprise information architecture, ensuring architectural consistency.Re15 The system should model how semantic modeling supports the overall information modeling process, improving modeling efficiency.Re16 The system should define promotion patterns to guide various business departments to gradually adopt smart grid semantic modeling methods.Re17 The system should support a hybrid deployment model of centralized and localized data storage to adapt to the needs of different business scenarios.Re18 The system should support a coexistence storage architecture for smart grid and non-smart grid data, avoiding data silos.Re19 The system should provide infrastructure components such as metadata repositories to support the operation of the technical architecture.Re20 The system should integrate analytical capabilities to support data insights and decision-making based on enterprise information.Re21 The system should establish an EIM capability center responsible for governance, knowledge dissemination, and best practice promotion.Re22 The system should support the promotion of smart grid EIM experience across the organization to improve overall data management levels.Re23 The system should introduce standardized data flow patterns, tools, and methodologies to improve data integration efficiency.Re24 The system should promote new logical data model patterns to enhance the organization's capabilities in modeling, maintenance, and reuse.Re25 The system should integrate information security controls at all architectural levels (business, data, application, technology) to ensure the security of data throughout its lifecycle.```.

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:The system also enables the inhabitants to visualize and control the status of the devices from a common user interface. Access control to some rooms may be required. The inhabitants can be authenticated by means of a PIN introduced in a keypad, passing an identification card by a card reader, or touching a fingerprint reader.  Inhabitants must be able to adjust the heater of the house to their preferred value.  Heaters can be in Celsius or in Fahrenheit. Additionally, heater control will adjust itself automatically to save energy. The daily schedule of each inhabitant is stored in the Smart Home gateway. In the periods of the day when the house is empty, the heater is disconnected and reconnected with enough time to reach the desired temperature when the inhabitants come back home. If a window is opened or closed, the heater control will take it into account to adjust itself. If the opening of a window would suppose a high energy consumption, because, for instance, the heater is trying to increase the room temperature and it is too cold outside, the inhabitants will be notified through the GUI.  Also, the Smart Home could choose to open or close windows to regulate the temperature inside the house. There are different types of graphical user interfaces (GUIs). These can be touch screens inside the house, mobile phones, or through a website available in the internet.  These interfaces allow monitoring and managing the different devices of the smart home. Inhabitants must be able to switch on/off and adjust the intensity of the different lights placed in a room. The adjustment can be performed specifying an intensity value or selecting a predefined value according to the current activities performed by the inhabitants, such as: watching TV, reading, sleeping, or during a night party. Besides, lights will be automatically switched on/off depending on several factors. If there is not natural light outside the house, the lights will be automatically switched on. Each time an inhabitant enters a room where there is not illumination enough, lights are automatically switched on, unless the room is in sleep mode which means that the inhabitants in the room may be sleeping. Presence simulation is activated when the inhabitants are in vacations or out of the house for long periods of time. This performs actions at certain times each day to give the impression that somebody is at home. The actions, like switching on and off lights or music, or opening and closing the blinds, can be determined by the inhabitants and are executed automatically. Fire control is responsible for identifying the presence of fire or smoke inside the home. When the Smart Home identifies a possible fire occurrence (based on smoke or temperature elevation), it emits an alarm, turns on the sprinklers, notifies the inhabitant through all the installed GUIs, and also sends an alarm to the fire department and/or other emergency group.  Finally, the system unlocks all doors and windows.  .

Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:The software to be developed shall accept output from existing patient monitoring equipment.#5.1.2 The software to be developed shall display graphical and numeric data at a remote location in real time.#5.1.3 The software to be developed shall graphically display output from an EKG oscilloscope monitor.#5.1.4 The software to be developed shall display numeric output from an EKG monitor.#5.1.5 The software to be developed shall display numeric percentages from a pulse oximeter.#5.1.6 The software to be developed shall display numeric values for systolic blood pressure.#5.1.7 The software to be developed shall display numeric values for diastolic blood pressure.#5.1.8 The software to be developed shall display numeric values for mean blood pressure.#5.1.9 The software to be developed shall display numeric values for body temperature.#5.1.10 The software to be developed shall display text values for patient identification.#5.1.11 The software to be developed shall display text values for time of day.#5.2.1 The software to be developed must display correct numeric pulse oximeter values at a remote location within five seconds. (Note. Correct values within 3% of actual [1])#5.2.2 The software to be developed must display correct numeric EKG values at a remote location within five seconds.#5.2.3 The software to be developed must display a correct graphical EKG oscilloscope waveform at a remote location within five seconds.#5.2.4 The software to be developed must display correct numeric blood pressure values at a remote location within five seconds.#5.2.5 The software to be developed must display correct numeric body temperature values at a remote location within five seconds.#5.2.6 The software to be developed must display the correct patient name.#5.2.7 The software to be developed shall display the correct time of day.#5.2.8 The software to be developed must operate twenty-four hours a day.#5.3.1 Acquisition of EKG Data will require solid, wet gel, banana socket, snap or tab disposable electrode sensors.#5.3.2 Electrode (EKG) sensors will attach to electronic monitoring equipment through 36 inch IEEE compliant universal lead wires. Refer to Requirement #5.3.1#5.3.3 Pulse oximetry data must be collected using Masimo finger sensor.#5.3.4 Masimo finger sensor must connect to Masimo interface cable. Refer to Requirement #5.3.3#5.4.1 Real-time Sensors and Diagnostics may need to be simulated due to inability to access authentic healthcare equipment#5.4.2 Data Integrity and Security are life critical issues with this system.#5.4.3 Redundant power and transmission should be addressed as this system is life critical..

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:When a user opens Picasa, it simply looks at the folders on his computer and displays the photos it finds. Picasa displays the file types that the user defined, in the folders he selected.#W2 When using editing tools in Picasa, the original files are never touched. The photo edits the user makes are only viewable in Picasa until he decides to save the changes. Then, Picasa creates a new version of the photo with the edits applied by the user, leaving the original file totally preserved.#W3 Picasa Web Albums provides 1GB of free storage to upload photos.#W4 The user can decide what photos Picasa displays. Picasa shows the user the photo and video file types and folders that he can select to display.#W5 A user can import photos into Picasa from many sources, including cameras, CDs, memory cards, scanners, webcams, and more. The imported photos are saved on the user's computer and displayed automatically in Picasa.#W6 To import photos from many sources the user should click Import, select the source of the new photos from the 'Import photos from' drop-down menu at the top. Then the user selects the destination folder on his computer for the new photos, from the 'Import to' drop-down menu at the bottom. He selects the specific photos to import and clicks the Import or 'Import All' button to import all the photos displayed.#W7 When a user likes to import the uploaded photos to Picasa Web Albums, the user should select the 'Upload' checkbox during the import action.#W8 Picasa supports organizing photos using three collections: Folders collection, Albums and People's collection.#W9 Picasa's Folders collection represents the folders on the user's computer. The user controls the folders that are scanned and displayed by Picasa. #W10 If a user makes changes to folders in Picasa, Picasa affect the corresponding folders on the user's computer hard drive. #W11 Unlike folders, albums exist only in Picasa. A user can create albums using virtual groups of photos taken from multiple folders on the computer. Picasa displays those photos without actually moving them, it's like a playlist for photos. #W12 When a user deletes or moves photos from an album, the original files remain in their original folders on the computer.#W13 A user can organize photos by the people in them. Picasa uses facial recognition technology to find and group similar faces together across the entire collection of photos. #W14 When a user adds name tags to groups of faces, Picasa creates new people albums.#W15 A user can click the Email button in Picasa to quickly email selected photos to friends and family.#W16 Picasa provides a variety of fixes and effects to improve almost any photo or to create something totally unique. #W17 A user can make simple edits, such as cropping, straightening, removing redeye, retouching blemishes, or adding text to your photos.#W18 A user can click on 'I'm Feeling Lucky' to try Picasa's all-in-one lighting and contrast fix. #W19 Picasa allows tuning photos. A user can use the sliders to adjust the color and lighting aspects of photos to produce more visually enhanced images. #W20 Picasa provides 12 effects to make the photos more interesting: Sharpen, convert to sepia or black and white, warm the photo, apply tint, saturate the colors, and more.#W21 Picasa provides advanced photo's editing effects such as Vignette, Orton-ish, Cross Process, and Comic Book etc.#W22 Picasa does not store the photos on the user's computer.#W23 Picasa always preserves the user's original photos. When a user uses the editing tools in Picasa, the original files are never touched. The edits of photos a user makes are only viewable in Picasa until he decides to save the changes. Even then, Picasa creates a new version of the photo with the edits applied, leaving the original file totally preserved.#W24 A user can control over whether his uploaded and Auto backup photos are stored at standard size, which is great for sharing on the web, or full size print quality, which uses more storage space. #W25 A user can upload an unlimited amount of standard size photos, but full size photos will be counted against his Google Drive storage quota.#W26 When a user opens Picasa Web Albums at https://picasaweb.google.com, Picasa displays the user's homepage, and show photos that are interesting to him.#W27 Picasa can present to a user his recent Albums. A user can see more than the latest albums he has uploaded, he can expand the list by clicking Show More Albums. The link of 'View All Albums' will take the user to a gallery of all his albums.#W28 Picasa can present to a user his recent activities. A user can Keep up with the most recently uploaded public albums from people he follow and any photos that have been shared with him.#W29 Picasa displays to user featured Photos. A user can view high quality photos from across the Picasa Community by clicking an individual photo to view it full size. #W30 Photos that have been featured will be badged with the Picasa Web Albums logo.#W31 Picasa allows sharing photos with others. A user can click the Share button to post photos to his Google+ stream or to send an email to a friend, inviting them to look through your Picasa Web album. #W32 A user can set his album visibility as public or as private as he'd like.#W33 Anyone on the web can view public albums. Public albums can be found on the user's public gallery, in web search results, on the user's Google profile, and in Google+.#W34 Picasa supports Limited Albums with a link. Those albums are visible to anyone with the link. They're technically visible to anyone but they include a unique authorization key in the web address. The key is a combination of letters and numbers that make the address difficult to guess.#W35 Limited albums are visible only to the people a user specifies, and those people must sign in to their Google Account to view the photos. Users without a Google Account will be prompted to create one. #W36 Google+ users have permission to re-share an album that was shared with them. #W37 Users within Google+, are able to see who else shared with his followers.#W38 Picasa supports 'Only you albums', which is the highest level of privacy. These albums are visible only to you. Changing an album to an 'Only you' type will wipe everyone off the album's 'Shared with' list.#W39 Picasa Web Albums is as social as the user wants it to be. #W40 A user can add users to the list of people he's following to receive updates when they add new photos to their public galleries. #W41 A user can add captions to all photos in an album from the same screen#W42 When uploading photos from the Picasa software, all photo captions will be uploaded with the user's photos. There is a 1024-character limit for captions displayed in Picasa Web Albums. Therefore captions longer than 1024 characters will be truncated appropriately for display in Picasa Web Albums.#W43 Changes made to captions in Picasa can automatically be reflected in the user's online albums by enabling Sync to Web in Picasa.#W44 A user can also manually prompt his captions created and edited in Picasa Web Albums to be synced down to his photos in Picasa. #W45 A user applies tags to label photos so that he and his friends can easily locate specific photos when searching on Picasa Web Albums. #W46 When a user uploads photos, any existing geographical information that is included in the photo EXIF data will be used to automatically map the photos.#W47 Users can drag-and-drop assigning map locations for albums and individual photos in Picasa Web Albums. #W48 Picasa supports 'Embedding photos on other sites'. A user can include a Picasa Web Albums slideshow, album, or image on his blog or website. The user needs to copy a small snippet of HTML and paste it in the source code of his site. This option is applicable to albums with visibilities set to be 'Public' or 'Limited, anyone with the link.'#W49 Picasa supports syncing changes. When a user enables the Sync to Web option in Picasa for a folder or album, edits made to his photos in Picasa are reflected immediately in the corresponding album in Picasa Web Albums.#W50 Once a user enables the Sync to Web feature, he can sync the following changes from Picasa to your web albums: Photos edit, addition or deletion, Addition of captions, tags or geotags, name tags and the order of photos.#W51 Once a user reaches his storage limit, any new photos he uploads, using sync to web that exceeds the size limit, will be automatically resized.#W52 When Sync to Web is enabled, changes made by user will only be synchronized in one direction, from Picasa to his web albums. However, the user can update captions, tags, and geo-tags from your web albums to Picasa using Refresh Online Status.#W53 A user can specify whether others can reproduce or share his work using Creative Commons licensing feature.#W54 When a user uploads photos to his accounts with Google products, Picasa automatically added the photos to his Picasa Web Albums account as well..

instruction: You are a professional business analyst who specializes in analyzing software requirements to define a software product line (SPL) feature model. You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:The software must allow input of patient data from patient (initial) home, secured access at Physician and Nurse Workstations, and from the data streaming real-time monitoring equipment.#3.1.1.1 A web-based system can allow initial patient information to be gathered by a dumb terminal in office or from patient own computer upon Email appointment verification hyperlinked to a web-based input screen.#3.1.2 The software must request username and password for access to data, only after authentication will allow access to the system.  #3.1.3 The software must require high levels of error correction and input validation.#3.1.3.1 Message box prompts would require a second entry of key data fields including name, DOB, Social Security Number, medications and allergies. Doctor inputs will similarly prompt proper code sets for diagnosis.#3.1.4 The software must allow browsing by the physician of historical medical information of his/her patients only.#3.1.5 The software must identify the patient by a unique numeric identifier derived from a function performed on the patient birth date.#3.1.5.1 Algorithm will be simply TODAY-BIRTHDAY = NUM & Doctor key & Increment (Increment will be added if duplicate number found in Database.) #3.1.6 The software must retrieve, update, and store data from multiple input locations including but not limited to hospital workstations, physician workstations, inbound emergency vehicles, and electronic monitoring equipment.#3.1.7 The software must allow patient to view their own medical record online allowing changes only to address, phone number, and insurer after initial input.#3.1.8 The software must only allow deletions by the vendor and only after archiving data in flat file format. #3.1.8.1 Deletions will only be performed at the request of the patient or the decedent heirs in compliance with HIPAA guidelines.#3.1.9 The software to be developed must display the correct patient name.#3.1.10 The software to be developed shall display the correct time of day in compliance with ISO 8601.  #3.1.11 The software to be developed must operate without interruption twenty-four hours a day.#3.1.12 The software must allow full and complete record search queries by physicians; also allow access to limited bloodwork, medication, and allergen information by EMT personnel and display results in order specified by operator.#3.1.13 The software must allow input of diagnostic imagery and FAT32 compression for storage and transmission of data.#3.1.14 The software must enable out put of real-time data and imagery from electronic diagnostic equipment through java applets which run in the web browser. Refer to 2.1#3.1.14.1 Nurses at workstation or doctors at desktop can access this data.#3.1.15 The software must retrieve and sort medical record information and allow for screen and print output of said information.#3.1.15.1 Print output will include name, DOB, and requested diagnostic information only.#3.1.16 The software must encrypt the data using Rijndael (AES) encryption algorithms from the database for transmission from point to point. #3.2.1 The software interface must follow design conventions which allow for familiar location of drop down menus, help etc. #3.2.2 Input errors will be returned in red with appropriate message box.#3.2.3 More than three attempts at login and failure will produce a red flag to system administrator.#3.3.1 The Physician software should be able to support at least three simultaneous users.#3.3.2 The Physician software should support diagnostics inputs (see section 5.1), three terminals and a SQL server database.#3.3.3 95% of the transactions shall be processed in less than one second.#3.3.4 Data should be secured and backed up every quarter hour.#3.3.5 Power supply should have a back up and a disaster recovery plan.#3.3.6 System should be operable 24 hours a day and accessible in real-time.#3.3.7 Secure Socket Layer 3.0 with 128 bit encryption will enable network security#3.4.1 Hardware, software, and data communication elements must be sourced within budgetary constraints..

You are aware that there are six possible types of constraints in a SPL feature model, encompassing mandatory, optional, or, xor, require and exclude. “mandatory” applies for individual mandatory features. “optional” applies for individual optional features. “or” applies for one-to-many constraints where at least one child feature must be present but two or more can coexist when a parent feature is present. “xor” applies for one-to-many constraints where child features coexist in a mutually exclusive way when a parent feature is present. “require” applies for two disconnected features that depend on each other. “exclude” applies for two disconnected features that are mutually exclusive. Please generate a SPL feature model based on the following software requirements:The software must allow input of patient data from the patient and the Physician.#4.1.1.1 A web-based system can allow initial patient information to be gathered by a dumb terminal in office or from patient own computer upon Email appointment verification hyperlinked to input screen.#4.1.2 The software must request username and password for access to data, only after authentication the system will allow access.  #4.1.3 The software must require high levels of error correction and input validation.#4.1.3.1 Message box prompts would require a second entry of key data fields including name, DOB, Social Security Number, medications and allergies. Doctor inputs will similarly prompt proper code sets for diagnosis.#4.1.4 The software must allow browsing by the physician of historical medical information of his/her patients only.#4.1.5 The software must identify the patient by a unique numeric identifier derived from a function performed on the patient birth date. #4.1.5.1 Algorithm will be simply TODAY-BIRTHDAY = NUM & Doctor Key & Increment (Increment will be added if duplicate number found in Database.) #4.1.6 The software must retrieve, update, and store data from multiple input locations including but not limited to hospital workstations, physician workstations, inbound emergency vehicles, and the electronic monitoring equipment.#4.1.7 The software must allow patient to view their own medical record online allowing changes only to address, Insurance and phone number.#4.1.8 The software must only allow deletions by the vendor and only after archiving data.#4.1.9 The software to be developed must display the correct patient name.#4.1.10 The software to be developed shall display the correct time of day in compliance with ISO 8601. #4.1.11 The software to be developed must operate twenty-four hours a day.#4.1.12 The software must allow full and complete record search queries by physicians; also allow access to limited bloodwork, medication, and allergen information by EMT personnel and display results in order specified by operator.#4.1.13 The software must allow input of diagnostic imagery and FAT32 compression for storage and transmission of data.#4.1.14 The software must enable out put of real-time data and imagery from electronic diagnostic equipment through java applets which run in the web browser.#4.1.14.1 Nurses at workstation or doctors at desktop can access this data. #4.1.15 The software must retrieve and sort medical record information and allow for screen and print output of said information.#4.1.15.1 Print output will include name, DOB, and requested diagnostic information only.#4.1.16 The software must encrypt the data using Rijndael (AES) encryption algorithms from the database for transmission from point to point.#4.2.1 The software interface must follow design conventions which allow for familiar location of drop down menus, help etc. #4.2.2 Input errors will be returned in red with appropriate message box.#4.2.3 More than three attempts at login and failure will produce a red flag to system administrator.#4.3.1 The Hospital software should be able to support up to 300 simultaneous users.#4.3.2The Hospital software should support an internet server, diagnostics inputs (see section 5.1), thirty two terminals and a SQL server database.#4.3.3 95% of the transactions shall be processed in less than one second.#4.3.4 Data should be secured and backed up every quarter hour.#4.3.5 Power supply should have a back up and a disaster recovery plan.#4.3.6 System should be operable 24 hours a day and accessible in real-time.#4.3.7 Secure Socket Layer 3.0 with 128 bit encryption will enable network security#4.3.8 Hardware, software, and data communication elements must be sourced within budgetary constraints..
